video.title: Learn Blockchain, Solidity, and Full Stack Web3 Development with JavaScript – 32-Hour Course
video.description:
This course will give you a full introduction into all of the core concepts related to blockchain, smart contracts, Solidity, ERC20s, full-stack Web3 dapps, decentralized finance (DeFi), JavaScript, TypeScript, Chainlink, Ethereum, upgradable smart contracts, DAOs, the graph, moralis, aave, IPFS, and more. Follow along with the videos and you'll be a blockchain wizard in no time!

💻 Code, resources, and support forum: https://github.com/smartcontractkit/full-blockchain-solidity-course-js
Please reference the repo for anything you need and feel free to leave issues and participate in the discussions.

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐
⌨️ (00:00:00) Lesson 0: Welcome To Blockchain
⌨️ (00:09:05) Lesson 1: Blockchain Basics
⌨️ (02:01:16) Lesson 2: Welcome to Remix! Simple Storage
⌨️ (03:05:34) Lesson 3: Remix Storage Factory
⌨️ (03:31:55) Lesson 4: Remix Fund Me
⌨️ (05:30:42) Lesson 5: Ethers.js Simple Storage
⌨️ (08:20:17) Lesson 6: Hardhat Simple Storage
⌨️ (10:00:48) Lesson 7: Hardhat Fund Me
⌨️ (12:32:57) Lesson 8: HTML / Javascript Fund Me (Full Stack / Front End)
⌨️ (13:41:02) Lesson 9: Hardhat Smart Contract Lottery
⌨️ (16:34:07) Lesson 10: NextJS Smart Contract Lottery (Full Stack / Front End)
⌨️ (18:51:36) Lesson 11: Hardhat Starter Kit
⌨️ (18:59:24) Lesson 12: Hardhat ERC20s
⌨️ (19:16:13) Lesson 13: Hardhat DeFi & Aave
⌨️ (20:28:51) Lesson 14: Hardhat NFTs 
⌨️ (23:37:03) Lesson 15: NextJS NFT Marketplace (Full Stack / Front End)
⌨️ (28:53:11) Lesson 16: Hardhat Upgrades
⌨️ (29:45:24) Lesson 17: Hardhat DAOs
⌨️ (31:28:32) Lesson 18: Security & Auditing 

✏️ Course developed by Patrick Collins. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/patrickcollins

Follow Patrick!
🐦 Twitter: https://twitter.com/PatrickAlphaC
📺 YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/c/PatrickCollins
✍️ Medium: https://medium.com/@patrick.collins_58673
💻 GitHub: https://github.com/PatrickAlphaC
🏢 LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/patrickalphac/

🎉 Special thanks to Sjors Ottjes. His amazing project, https://subtitletools.com, helped make the subtitles possible.

👾 Raymond Odero

replies.text: The price is mostly based around speculation, It's the same with stocks and houses which are also collapsing financially. topLevelComment.text:
5:11:53 
for those of you guys wondering what's the difference between const and immutable 
Both immutable and constant are keywords that can be used on state variables to restrict modifications to their state. 

The difference is that constant variables can never be changed after compilation, while immutable variables can be set within the constructor.

How to add Specific Version of HardHat using Yarn ?

HARDHAT SETUP 
Use this below code
yarn add --dev hardhat@2.9.3

And Not the following line
yarn add --dev hardhat, This code makes us to install the latest version.

HardHat Specific Version is used for  Lession 6, 7 & etc,  It's Most Helpfull for Lession 7.

Thank You.

topLevelComment.author: Sumit Patil
topLevelComment.text:
[ Tip : hardhat-deploy ] (10:48:18) Using "tags" we can run particular scripts.
For example, you can include a tag in your particular deploy script, lets say "mock1".
Include this in your deploy script : 
     module.exports.tags = [ "mock1" ]
And use the command :
     yarn hardhat deploy --tags mock1
And this will deploy only the scripts which include "mock1" tag.

topLevelComment.text: Why does the block hast to start with 4 zeros (0000)?  01:10:46

replies.author: Bloodday Ramnarok
replies.text:
when you hash some data you get as a result a big number of fixed length.

I'll give you an example, in computers all the data (words, images, music, etc) is represented by numbers, lets say that I create a function that take those numbers and adds them up and sould return a 4 digits number.

with the following data:

1397581999575919388696020210913471239034858102319572010394867672940391857623

I start adding up each digit starting from the right side, the result is 349. since I have to return 4 digits in this example I fill it up with 0.

0349 is the result of my made up hashing function.

but what happens if the result is too large and haave more than 4 digits?

well for my made up hashing function i decide to repeat the process to get a number that 4 digits or less.

now whn you have a large amount of data (blockchain a transaction, or an image). it gets a bit tricky to guess what kind of nummber you will get, you you have to calculate the hash yourself.

calculating the hash is trivial, in the proof of work model you want a way to know that someone has done the calculations and the first that do it correclty will get a reward, so you make it a bit harder, but how?

in the transaction you have a field that can be filled by the miner, in that filed the miner will put data, and you make the problem hard by asking for a repeating number.

you set the dificulty by increasing or decreasing the repetition count of that number.

that's what bitcoin does, it calculates the transactions in last hours and adjus the dificulty by requiring more or less ceroes at the start of the hash result.

in the video example they use 4 as an example that's easy to solve.

replies.author: Sean Anih
replies.text:
I got stuck there too, so I suggest using whatever names make it easier for you to understand.
I will try to explain:

SimpleStorage(1) simplestorage(2) = new SimpleStorage()(3)
(1) is the data type "SimpleStorage", which means the data type IS the contract we imported
(2) is the name chosen for the variable; similar to "uint number", except the type and name have similar names in our tutorial
(3) means the variable "simpleStorage" is being defined as a copy of the SimpleStorage(1) contract

Hope that helps!

replies.author: Max
replies.text: @Study Light & Insight no. Miners are securizing the transactions and get paid for it (by the gas fees of each transaction). Mining is less and less profitable since Ethereum 2.0 (the merge) is up. This new technology secures the transactions by the mechanism of proof of stake (you stake eth on transactions to validate it) instead of proof of work (you make very difficult computations and use a lot of energy to do it). So it is not possible anymore to mine Ethereum which was the most profitable coin to mine nowadays. So unless a more profitable coin shows up, I would say you to go for smart contract developping

topLevelComment.author: Rick Farina
topLevelComment.text:
At hour 4:15:51 we are calculating price using AggregatorV3Interface.

Given: 
price = 109326408958   // 1093_26408958
decimals = 8 

The code suggest that we perform the following:
return ( uint256(price) * (1**decimals) );  // multiplication



in the calculator, this results in: 1.09326409×10¹⁹

Shouldn't this be the following:
return ( uint256(price) / (1**decimals) );  // division
in the calculator, this results in: 1093.26408958

which I think is the correct answer.

Can you provide clarity. Am I mistaken on this calculation?
Thanks,
Rick

topLevelComment.author: Rick Farina
topLevelComment.text:
I can already tell this course is extremely valuable. But there are 3 things that I'd like to comment on.
1. The statement that Smart Contracts can't be hacked is not true. Hacks take place nearly every week.
2. The statement that Smart Contracts are immutable is not true. Using Updateable contracts allows you to change the business rules.
3. The statement that Smart Contracts are always there is not true. Running selfDestruct can close a contract so it can no longer be used.

Any thoughts???

topLevelComment.author: Ayush Dabral
topLevelComment.text:
Notes for me :

1 . Memory, calldata or storage is required for array, struct or mapping type. String is also considered as char array so for this as well it needed.
     memory : temp storage, can alter the data.
     calldata  : temp storage, can't alter the data.
     storage   : permanent storage, can alter the data

2. To transfer the eth to an address, we have 3 methods:
     transfer.
     send.
     call.

3. Special functions (which don't require explicit "function" keyword ):
     constructor() : to initialize the contract variables.
     receive() : will trigger when transact without providing any CALLDATA (msg.data) //require function needs to be there else will trigger fallback function,.
     fallback() : will trigger when transact by providing any CALLDATA (msg.data).


For gas optimization :

1. use constant or immutable while declaring a variable.
2. use if(condition) { revert errorMsg(); } instead of require(condition, 'error msg');  //make sure to initialize that function first as : error errorMsg();.
